column2: Which of the following is a transaction isolation level as specified by SQL standard?

column1: Explanation: Serializable, repeatable read, read committed and read uncommitted are the four levels of transactions."

column2: State true or false: Serializable level may allow both serializable and non-serializable executions

column1: Explanation: Serializable level generally allows only serializable executions but in some special cases, it may also allow non-serializable execution."

column2: ________ allows only committed data to be read and further requires that no other transaction is allowed to update it between two reads of a data item by a transaction.

column1: Explanation: Repeatable read allows only committed data to be read and further requires that no other transaction is allowed to update it between two reads of a data item by a transaction. However, the transaction may not be serializable with respect to other transactions."

column2: ________ allows only committed data to be read, but does not require repeatable reads

column1: Explanation: Read committed allows only committed data to be read, but does not require repeatable reads. For instance, between two reads of a data item by the transaction, another transaction may have updated the data item and committed."

column2: ___________ allows uncommitted data to be read

column1: Explanation: Real uncommitted allows uncommitted data to be read. It is the lowest isolation level allowed by SQL."

column2: State true or false: All the isolation levels disallow dirty writes

column1: Explanation: All the isolation levels above additionally disallow dirty writes, that is, they Disallow writes to a data item that has already been written by another transaction that has not yet committed or aborted."
Explanation: Timestamp is allotted when execution of a transaction begins."

column2: In ___________ isolation each transaction is given its own version of the database

column1: Explanation: In snapshot isolation, each transaction is given its own version or snapshot of the database on which it can operate."

column2: What is the disadvantage of locking?
Has a poor degree of concurrency

column1: View Answer",Answer: Locking has a poor degree of concurrency. It in fact has no concurrency at all.

column2: If a transaction has obtained a __________ lock, it can read but cannot write on the item

column1: Explanation: If a transaction Ti has obtained a shared-mode lock (denoted by S) on item Q, then Ti can read, but cannot write, Q. "

column2: If a transaction has obtained a ________ lock, it can both read and write on the item

column1: Explanation: If a transaction has obtained an exclusive mode lock, then it can both read and write on the item on which it in operating. "

column2: A transaction can proceed only after the concurrency control manager ________ the lock to the transaction

column1: Explanation: A transaction can proceed only after the concurrency control manager grants the lock to the transaction."

column2: If a transaction can be granted a lock on an item immediately in spite of the presence of another mode, then the two modes are said to be ________

column1: Explanation:  If a transaction can be granted a lock on an item immediately in spite of the presence of another mode, then the two modes are said to be compatible. "

column2: A transaction is made to wait until all ________ locks held on the item are released

column1: Explanation: A transaction is made to wait until all compatible locks held on the item are released. This ensures that no other transaction is concurrently accessing the same item."

column2: State true or false: It is not necessarily desirable for a transaction to unlock a data item immediately after its final access

column1: Explanation: It is not necessarily desirable for a transaction to unlock a data item immediately after its final access because serializability may be violated due to this. "

column2: The situation where no transaction can proceed with normal execution is known as ________

column1: Explanation: The situation where no transaction can proceed with normal execution is known as a deadlock. "

column2: The protocol that indicates when a transaction may lock and unlock each of the data items is called as __________

column1: Explanation: The protocol that indicates when a transaction may lock and unlock each of the data items is called as locking protocol. Locking protocols restrict the number of schedules. "

column2: If a transaction Ti may never make progress, then the transaction is said to be ____________

column1: Explanation: If a transaction Ti may never make progress, then the transaction is said to be starved. "

column2: The two phase locking protocol consists which of the following phases?
More than one of the mentioned

column1: Explanation: The two phased locking protocol consists of the growing phase and the shrinking phase."

column2: If a transaction may obtain locks but may not release any locks then it is in _______ phase

column1: Explanation:  If a transaction may obtain locks but may not release any locks then it is in growing phase. Growing phase is a phase in two phased locking protocol."

column2: If a transaction may release locks but may not obtain any locks, it is said to be in ______ phase

column1: Explanation: If a transaction may release locks but may not obtain any locks, it is said to be in shrinking phase. Shrinking phase is a phase in two phased locking protocol."

column2: A system is in a _______ state if there exists a set of transactions in which every transaction is waiting for another transaction in the set.

column1: Explanation: A system is in a deadlock state if there exists a set of transactions in which every transaction is waiting for another transaction in the set."

column2: Which of the following is not a method in deadlock handling

column1: Explanation: Deadlock distribution is not a method in deadlock handling whereas, deadlock prevention is followed by deadlock detection and deadlock recovery."
Explanation: Preemption and transaction rollbacks, wait and die scheme, wound wait scheme are all different methods of deadlock prevention."

column2: State true or false: Wait die scheme is a non-preemptive technique

column1: Explanation: The wait-die scheme is a non-preemptive technique. When transaction Ti requests a data item currently held by Tj , Ti is allowed to wait only if it has a timestamp smaller than that of Tj (that is, Ti is older than Tj ). Otherwise, Ti is rolled back (dies)."

column2: Lock timeouts have which of the following advantages?

column1: Explanation: In lock timeout method, unnecessary rollbacks do not occur, transactions do not starve and it is also easy to implement and is hence widely used if transactions are short and long waits are likely to be due to deadlocks."
Explanation: The wait for graph describes deadlocks precisely. Existence of a cycle in this graph implies that a deadlock will occur."

column2: How do we generally recover from a deadlock?
By rolling back all the transactions
By rolling back only a selected number of transactions

column1: Explanation: We generally recover from deadlocks by rolling back only a selected number of transactions"

column2: State true or false: Partial rollback is not possible.

column1: Explanation: Partial rollback is possible but it requires the system too maintain an additional amount of information on the states of the transactions."

column2: Which of the following steps must be taken while choosing a victim?
Number of transactions involved in rollback
Data items used by the transaction

column1: Explanation: While choosing a victim we much choose the one with a minimum cost. That is the one which avoids starvation, the one with the least number of transaction involved in the rollback and the one with the least amount of data items used."

column2: Which of the following cannot be used to implement a timestamp

column1: Explanation: An external time counter cannot be used to implement a timestamp. System clock and a logical counter can be used."

column2: A logical counter is _________ after a new timestamp has been assigned

column1: Explanation: A logical counter is incremented after a new timestamp has been assigned everytime."

column2: The largest timestamp of any transaction that can execute write(Q) successfully
The largest timestamp of any transaction that can execute read(Q) successfully
The smallest timestamp of any transaction that can execute write(Q) successfully
The smallest timestamp of any transaction that can execute read(Q) successfully

column1: Explanation: W-timestamp(Q) denotes The largest timestamp of any transaction that can execute write(Q) successfully."

column2: The largest timestamp of any transaction that can execute write(Q) successfully
The largest timestamp of any transaction that can execute read(Q) successfully
The smallest timestamp of any transaction that can execute write(Q) successfully
The smallest timestamp of any transaction that can execute read(Q) successfully

column1: Explanation: R-timestamp(Q) denoted the largest timestamp of any transaction that can execute read(Q) successfully."

column2: A ________ ensures that any conflicting read and write operations are executed in timestamp order

column1: Explanation: A timestamp ordering protocol ensures that any conflicting read and write operations are executed in timestamp order."

column2: The default timestamp ordering protocol generates schedules that are

column1: Explanation: The timestamp ordering protocol generates schedules that are non-recoverable. But it can be extended to make the schedules recoverable."

column2: State true or false: The Thomas write rule has a greater potential concurrency than the timestamp ordering protocol

column1: Explanation: The Thomas write rule has a greater potential concurrency than the timestamp ordering protocol. This is because it is a modified version of the timestamp ordering protocol in which obsolete write operations can be ignored under certain circumstances."

column2: Which of the following timestamp based protocols generates serializable schedules?

column1: Explanation: Thomas write rule protocol generates serializable schedules that no other protocol can generate."

column2: In timestamp ordering protocol, suppose that the transaction Ti issues read(Q) and TS(Ti)<W-timestamp(Q), then

column1: Explanation: Suppose that transaction Ti issues read(Q). If TS(Ti ) < W-timestamp(Q), then Ti needs to read a value of Q that was already overwritten. Hence, the read operation is rejected, and Ti is rolled back."

column2: In timestamp ordering protocol, suppose that the transaction Ti issues write(Q) and TS(Ti)<W-timestamp(Q), then

column1: Explanation: In timestamp ordering protocol, suppose that the transaction Ti issues write(Q) and TS(Ti)<W-timestamp(Q), then the value of Q that Ti is producing was needed previously, and the system assumed that the value would never be produced. Hence the system rejects the write(Q) operation and the transaction Ti rolls back."

column2: The _________ requires each transaction executes in two or three different phases in its lifetime

column1: Explanation: The validation protocol requires each transaction to execute in two or three different phases in its lifetime depending on whether it is a read only or an update transaction. "

column2: During __________ phase, the system reads data and stores them in variables local to the transaction.

column1: Explanation: During the read phase, the system reads data and stores them in variables local to the transaction. It performs all write operations on temporary local variables without updates on the actual database. "

column2: During the _________ phase the validation test is applied to the transaction

column1: Explanation: During the validation phase, the validation test is applied to the transaction. This determines whether the transaction is allowed to proceed or not without causing a violation of serializability. "

column2: During the _______ phase, the local variables that hold the write operations are copied to the database

column1: Explanation: During the write phase, the local variables that hold the write operations are copied to the database. Read only operations omit this phase. "

column2: Read only operations omit the _______ phase

column1: Explanation: Read only operations do not allow write operation to be performed on them. So, they omit the write phase but execute the read and validation phases. "

column2: Which of the following timestamp is used to record the time at which the transaction started execution?

column1: Explanation: There are three different timestamps for each transaction start(i), validation(i), finish(i). Start(i) is used to record the time at which the transaction execution started."

column2: Which of the following timestamps is used to record the time when a transaction has finished its read phase?

column1: Explanation: There are three different timestamps for each transaction start(i), validation(i), finish(i). The validation phase is used to record the time at which a transaction has finished its read phase and has started its validation phase."

column2: Which of the following timestamps is used to record the time when a database has completed its write operation?

column1: Explanation: There are three different timestamps for each transaction start(i), validation(i), finish(i). Finish(i) is used to record the time when a transaction has finished its write phase."

column2: State true or false: Locking and timestamp ordering force a wait or rollback whenever a conflict is detected.

column1: Explanation: Locking and timestamp ordering force a wait or rollback whenever a conflict is detected. This property is called pessimism of locking and timestamp protocols."

column2: State true or false: We determine the serializability order of validation protocol by the validation ordering technique

column1: Explanation: We determine the serializability order of the validation protocol by the timestamp ordering technique. There is no technique called as the validation ordering technique to determine the serializability order of the validation protocol. "

column2: In _______ schemes, each write operation creates a new version of Q

column1: Explanation: In multiversion schemes, each write operation creates a new version of Q. When a transaction issues a read operation, the concurrency control manager selects one of the versions of Q to be read. "

column2: If the first update is overwritten by a second, it is called as a _______ update

column1: Explanation: If the first update is overwritten by a second, it is called as a lost update. This generally occurs whenever two transactions are allowed to write on the database. "

column2: State true or false: Snapshot isolation prevents lost updates

column1: Explanation: Snapshot isolation prevents lost updates because it does not allow two transactions to simultaneously write on the same database. "

column2: Which of the following is a variant of snapshot isolation
More than one of the mentioned

column1: Explanation: First committer wins and first updater wins are two different variations of snapshot isolation. "

column2: Under ________ the system uses locking mechanism that applies only to updates

column1: Explanation: Under first updater wins, the system uses a locking mechanism that applies only to updates. Read operations do not get affected by this mechanism. "

column2: The situation in which each pair of transactions has read a data written by the other, but there is no data written by the transactions is called as _______

column1: Explanation: The situation in which each pair of transactions has read a data written by the other, but there is no data written by the transactions is called as write skew."

column2: Oracle uses __________ for the serializable isolation level

column1: Explanation: Oracle uses snapshot isolation for the serializable isolation level. PostgreSQL also uses only snapshot isolation for the serializable isolation level. "

column2: State true or false: Snapshot isolation has low overhead

column1: Explanation: Snapshot isolation is attractive in practice because it has a relatively very low overhead. "

column2: In ________ no two aborts occur unless two concurrent transactions update the same data item.

column1: Explanation: In snapshot isolation no two aborts occur unless two concurrent transactions update the same data item. This makes snapshot isolation attractive but it does not ensure serializability. "

column2: Which of the following transactions can multiversion two phase locking protocol not differentiate.

column1: Explanation: The multiversion two phase locking protocol cannot differentiate double operator transactions but it can differentiate between read only transactions and update transactions. "

column2: ________ deletes a data item from a database

column1: Explanation: Delete(Q) deletes a data item from a database. Insert(Q) inserts a new data item Q into the database and assign Q an initial value. "

column2: Which of the following does not lock the entire index

column1: Explanation: Index locking avoids locking the entire index. Any transaction that inserts a tuple into a relation must insert information into every index maintained on the relation. "

column2: Which of the following is included in the operational mechanism of the index locking protocol?
Every transaction must have at least one index
A transaction that performs a lookup must acquire a shared lock on all the index leaf nodes that it accesses
The rule of the two phase locking mechanism must be observed

column1: Explanation: The operational mechanism of the index locking protocol includes, every transaction must have at least one index. A transaction that performs lookup must acquire a shared lock on all the index leaf nodes that it accesses. The rule of the two phase locking mechanism must be followed. "

column2: _________ is a form of two degree consistency designed for programs that iterate over tuples of a relation by using cursors.

column1: Explanation: Cursor stability is a form of two degree consistency designed for programs that iterate over tuples of a relation by using cursors. It ensures that the tuple that is currently being processed is locked in shared mode and any modified tuples are locked in exclusive mode until the transaction commits. "

column2: Transactions that involve user interactions are called __________

column1: Explanation: Transactions that involve user interactions are called as conversation. These are named differently to differentiate them from regular transactions. Validation using version numbers is very useful for such transactions. "

column2: State true or false: Key value locking provides increased concurrency

column1: Explanation: Key value locking provides increased concurrency. Using key value improperly however might cause phantom phenomenon to occur. "

column2: To prevent the phantom phenomenon, _______ is used

column1: Explanation: The failure of a system to prevent a non serialized tuple when two transactions conflict with each other is called as phantom phenomenon. To prevent the phantom phenomenon, the next key locking is used. "

column2: Which of the following does cursor stability ensure
The tuple that is currently being processed by the iteration is locked in shared mode
The tuple that is currently being processed is not locked in shared mode
Any modified tuples are not locked in exclusive mode

column1: Explanation: Cursor stability ensures that the tuple that is currently being processed by the iteration is locked in shared mode and any modified tuples are locked in exclusive mode until the transaction commits. "

column2: State true or false: Exclusive locks are held until transaction commit in degree two consistency

column1: Explanation: Exclusive locks are held until transaction commit in degree two consistency, no transaction can read an uncommitted value. "

column2: Which of the following can cause a transaction failure
More than one of the mentioned

column1: Explanation: Logical errors and system errors are the two types of errors that can generally cause transaction failures. "

column2: If the transaction can no longer continue with its normal execution because of some internal condition, it is called as a _________

column1: Explanation: If the transaction can no longer continue with its normal execution because of some internal condition, it is called as a logical error such as bad input, data not found, overflow or resource limit exceeded. "

column2: If a system has entered and undesirable state due to which it is unable to continue with normal execution, it is called as _________

column1: Explanation: If a system has entered and undesirable state due to which it is unable to continue with normal execution, it is called as a system error. The transaction however can be re-executed at a later time. "

column2: If there is a hardware malfunction or a bug in the database that causes the loss of content of volatile storage, it is called as ________

column1: Explanation: If there is a hardware malfunction or a bug in the database that causes the loss of content of volatile storage, it is called as a system crash. The data in the non-volatile storage remains intact and it is not corrupted. "

column2: The assumption that the hardware errors bring the system to a halt is called as ________

column1: Explanation: The assumption that the hardware errors bring the system to a halt is called as fail-stop assumption. Well-designed systems have numerous internal checks that bring a system to a halt whenever there is an error. Hence, the fail stop assumption is a reasonable one. "

column2: Which of the following is not a classification of storage

column1: Explanation: Volatile storage, non-volatile storage and stable storage are three different classifications of storage. Volatile storage is the least secure whereas stable storage is the most secure among them. "

column2: If a failure has occurred in the midst of a transfer, it is called as _________

column1: Explanation: If a failure has occurred in the midst of a transfer, it is called as partial failure. After a partial failure, the destination has incorrect information. "

column2: State true or false: The destination block has incorrect information in case of a total failure

column1: Explanation: In case of total failure, the failure occurs sufficiently early during the transfer that the destination block remains intact. Thus there is no corruption of data at the destination. "

column2: The partitions of the database into fixed length storage units are called as __________

column1: Explanation: The database is partitioned into fixed length storage units called as blocks. Blocks are the units of data transfer and may contain several data items. "

column2: The blocks residing on the disk are referred to as ___________

column1: Explanation: The blocks residing on the disk are referred to as physical blocks. The blocks residing temporarily in the main memory are referred to as buffer blocks. "

column2: The area of memory where blocks temporarily reside is called as ________

column1: Explanation: The area of memory where blocks temporarily reside is called as the disk buffer. The disk buffer is used to store the buffer blocks which hold temporary data. "

column2: The most widely used structure for recording database modification is called as _______

column1: Explanation: The most widely used structure for recording database modification is called as a log. The log is a sequence of log records recording all the update activities in the database. "

column2: An update log record describes a ________ database write

column1: Explanation: An update log record describes a single database write. It has four fields in it which are, transaction identifier, data-item identifier, old value, new value. "

column2: Which of the following fields does the update log record have?

column1: Explanation: An update log record describes a single database write. It has four fields in it. The update log record has a transaction identifier, data-item identifier, old value, new value. "

column2: The unique identifier of the transaction that performed the write operation is called as _______

column1: Explanation: The unique identifier of the transaction that performed the write operation is called as transaction identifier. This is a field in the update log record. "

column2: The value of the data item prior to the write is called as _________

column1: Explanation: The value of the data item prior to the write is called as old value. This is stored in the update log record. "

column2: If a transaction does not modify the database until it has committed it is said to use a  _______ modification technique
More than one of the mentioned

column1: Explanation:  If a transaction does not modify the database until it has committed it is said to use a deferred modification technique. Deferred modification has the overhead that transactions need to make local copies of all updated data items. "

column2: We say that a transaction has been ________ when its commit log record has been output to stable storage.

column1: Explanation: We say that a transaction has been committed when its commit log record has been output to stable storage. At that point, all the earlier records have already been output to stable storage. "

column2: State true or false: Using checkpoints reduces overhead

column1: Explanation: Using checkpoints reduces overhead because the search process is time consuming and searching for transactions does not take place if we use checkpoints. "

column2: A __________ checkpoint is a checkpoint where transactions are allowed to perform updates even while buffer blocks are being written out.

column1: Explanation: A fuzzy checkpoint is a checkpoint where transactions are allowed to perform updates even while buffer blocks are being written out. "

column2: If the database modifications occur while the transaction is still active, the transaction is said to use the __________ modification technique
More than one of the mentioned

column1: Explanation: If the database modifications occur while the transaction is still active, the transaction is said to use the immediate modification technique. Deferred modification has overhead whereas immediate modification doesnâ€™t have any overhead. "
